job_title: Instructional Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Overall, the SoM and the hospitals have higher workload demands than the other schools within the Stanford network, but the pay is slightly higher than the university. Like every work environment, there are politics that are either managed well or undermanaged, depending on the leadership of that department. I worked for the Continuing Medical Education department in SoM and found the people to be kind and hard-working. Also, the mission to improve patient care is a motivating factor for the work in SoM and the hospitals. Stanford offers several great benefits, including childcare and home-buying programs that outweigh the below-market pay for those living in the Bay Area. It all depends on your priorities.
cons: CME is not a department I would recommend for someone who is looking for work-life balance. The leadership in this department could use some further development to help strengthen their leadership skills. The leaders are overworked and lack strategic vision, making it difficult to do the work more efficiently.

job_title: Life Science Research Professional II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The campus looks really nice
cons: Some people are not nice

review_title: Good stepping stone for those that want to continue to med school
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: The people on my team were good for the most part. Stanford looks good on your resume.
cons: Pay is lower than private industry.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros: can set own time schedule
cons: chronically underpaid and no possibility to move up

review_title: Good employer, but loyal only to itself
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: Good benefits; flexible work (depending on where you are in the org); good infrastructure; very good support from shared services like IT and Finance; ridiculously smart people to work with; great reputation, brand, prestige. Access to fantastic facilities (libraries, gyms, etc). Pretty good cafeterias, coffee shops. etc on campus. Reasonably supportive culture.
cons: Bureaucratic; Many "lifers" who have lost their sense of urgency (9 to 5 culture among staff). Pay is mediocre (brand is part of the compensation). Parking is a nightmare and parking permits are expensive (or you end up parking miles away or taking shuttles). Culture: Staff is third-class citizen - the hierarchy is clearly Faculty (academic council, then "clinical faculty"), then students, then staff, then everyone else. Somewhere in there are also nurses and patients and techs but they are kind of ignored by the school. Culturally homogeneous, probably not a good place to work if you are the only Republican in California, especially if you are argumentative and you want to discuss culture or politics (btw I'm not, but it is very obvious). In the rare case where an employee annoys or embarrasses the school (union activists, people who get negative media, people who criticize or sue Stanford, regardless of whether they had a good reason, people who do something that makes the University worry about getting sued or embarrassed, people who say stupid stuff that is unpopular with students, etc.) the University/School has zero loyalty to you, no matter how well you performed or how long you've been there or what position you held (in that sense, they treat everyone the same - whether you were a Dean or a janitor). They will drop you faster than a hot potato, as quietly as possible. I have NEVER seen them stand up for an employee in any sort of controversy.

review_title: Can be a good place to be for a few years if your lab understands how to handle high-turnover
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator Associate in Stanford, CA
pros:
Good place to network if you're looking to go further into clinical research or medicine
- Great way to get patient facing experience if you're aiming a few years experience pre medical or graduate school
- Some labs include CRCs on their papers for publishing (but not all)
- PTO and sick time banks accumulate quickly and the PTO has a reasonably high cap
cons:
- Very limited upward mobility. Unless you want to aim for management in order to move up at all you either have to leave for clinical research industry jobs, go to medical school, or go to graduate school.
- Your experience will vary depending on your PI and your manager, some labs are amazing and some are awful.
- Clinical research on the academic side has high turnover by nature, many if not most CRCs are there for 1-3 years working on graduate school, medical school preparation, or figuring out next steps career-wise and don't intend to stay very long-term. If your lab isn't set up to handle this frequent changeover it can be stressful and contribute to burnout.
- Depending on the research (ie with rare disease, oncology, or similar areas where you're dealing with very sick or dying people) it can be emotionally demanding and exhausting.

job_title: Research Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Great name recognition on resume once departed.
cons: It’s shocking to see how much the work is really just about propping up the egos of tenured faculty. Watch out for who you decide to work for and make sure you “play the game” to get what you need out of being affiliated with Stanford.

review_title: Big Egos With Too Few Adults
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: The benefits are generous and staff can use all of the amazing facilities, attend lectures, etc.
cons:
The bureaucracy is thick, and nothing is laid out in a chart of any kind, so  lot of my time was spent trying to figure out what my job was and was not and who I needed to consult with about what.

The biggest problem, as another reviewer said, is that some departments are toxic because the powerful faculty members can do whatever they want. Some staff hitch their wagons and are promoted/given raises/etc. And some staff have been at Stanford long enough that they basically can't be fired, so they can also create a very negative environment as well with a lot of complaints or simply by not doing their job beyond the absolute minimum.

Also, though the benefits on paper are very good, the bureaucracy tries to make sure you can access as few of them as possible, so ask very specifically about which benefits you get and under what circumstances that might change.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great scope for career improvement
cons: No attention to work/life balance

review_title: Great place, but salary not sufficient to survive in the area
job_title: Life Science Research Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros: great research opportunities with good resources for collaborations, networking, outstanding seminars by  famous scientists, possibility of doing incredibly good science with extremely smart people, nice campus and good benefits, depending on the PI you are getting mentored and encouraged to attend conferences, can advance in your career
cons:
individual experience depends very much on your PI - there are many good ones, but also several really bad ones, so beware!
salary way too low to make ends meet in Bay Area
not much done to retain mid-level staff, i.e. in terms of upwards mobility, salary increases and such
annual 3% raises are a joke and barely keep up with cost of living increases, too little when you start out with a low salary
high work load and stressful environment with lots of pressure
Putting in 55+hrs per week and still not being able to live off Stanford salary makes me question if I should take a second job.

job_title: Faculty Affairs in Stanford, CA
pros: Interesting to work in a vital environment where the professors truly are world-class experts (*pros and cons to that) and where the students are bright and motivated.  Great insurance plan, and I overall enjoyed my tasks and co-workers at the support level.  Salary was industry-average for the Bay Area, and there was a stipend benefit to be able to take continuing education classes/workshops. Most of the research faculty I served were dedicated, brilliant individuals and a pleasure to work with.
cons: It's an academic environment, and I'm sad to say, some of the stereotypes are true. While there are many professional and lovely faculty at Stanford, there appears to be at least one pseudo-rock star in every department who believes his/her own press and treats support staff shabbily.   Difficult to get promoted out of a role once you're in it - it appears that faculty prefer to keep staff in their place. Staff are almost a lower caste.

job_title: Director in Stanford, CA
pros: Flexible hours and stanford university perks
cons: Lack of uniform culture and values

job_title: QA Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits, opportunity to learn
cons: Still learning how to combine academic vs industry

job_title: Life Science Research Professional in Palo Alto, CA
pros: learn brand new skills with hands on teaching
cons: long hours, not a typical 9-5

job_title: Associate Director in Stanford, CA
pros: Smart people, good systems, amazing resources
cons: Internal politics, unclear job descriptions

review_title: Research Assistant - Perspectives from Undergraduate Experience
job_title: Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: There are several avenues to receive financial compensation for work with lab groups/departments willing to collaborate or looking for support, especially for students or graduates (e.g. Federal Work Study, Bio-X, Undergraduate Advising and Research (UAR) grants, internal funding, etc.). The facilities and technology tend to be top of the line. There is active support for handling hazardous waste & materials and up-to-date, low- or no-cost training for certain techniques and best practices. Frequent seminars and lectures covering science, technology, and community, from reviews to frontiers.
cons: Experience is highly dependent on individual lab group and mentor. Some labs are struggling for funding, which limits the number/scope of their projects to those specifically supported by current grants. Others have more flexibility. Some PIs or graduate/post-doctoral students make a point of fostering young scientists. Unfortunately, many labs rely on lower-ranking collaborators for "grunt work" (e.g. data analysis, chemical inventory), while only PIs and high-status researchers are involved in higher level activities (e.g. discussion of goals, findings, and their meaning, decisions future directions, publications). As a whole, there is too much focus on image and profit per square foot of lab space (literally), rather than impact and wellbeing.

job_title: Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great, challenging environment for personal growth
cons: It can become a bit busy.

job_title: Anonymous in Stanford, CA
pros: You get to work with talented academic people and have access to good equipment.
cons:
The deceptive manager seemed supportive and nice at the beginning to attract you, but then all lies surface if you bother to ask. 

The manager is always trying to make people overwork and not pay them (illegal). He will ask employees to work on holidays and threaten them if they report these hours, which is completely against Stanford's policy.

This happens to workers who don't have much leverage such as new graduates, contractors, volunteer workers, and exchange scholars. Full-time employees are treated differently because of the law. At one point, the manager successfully committed 'constructive dismissal' (illegal) by coercing an employee to leave under 'bad' working conditions.

I am surprised the manager has not been fired yet as he covers up all his illegal activities by threatening employees. This review is no mistake, they have now moved outside Stanford, but the manager is still the same. I am not sure if they are still part of Stanford's School of Medicine, but they are still called Bioadd.

Be careful, this employer is a predator who takes advantage of the less fortunate.

job_title: Program Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- If you're looking for a 9-5pm job with ok benefits, this is the place for you. 

- It's easy to stay under the radar and do the minimum amount of work. 

- Beautiful location, close to downtown Palo Alto
cons:
Here are just a few:

- If you are the ambitious type, this place is not for you.  Management is usually based on seniority and not on the quality of your work, skills or your contributions.  

- It's very much an institution, so any new ideas are difficult to implement.  Expect to have a lot of resistance because people there prefer status quo.  No one likes to do more work or try to be more efficient with their time

- Staff and administration are generally treated like a number, but for faculty and students the university really treats them well

- Administration is overworked, and the pay as well as the bonuses and increases are minimal.  Good work is not really recognized and can't be compensated as well as industry.  If you're ok with cake and pizza for a job well done, then you'll be very happy.  If you're looking for bonuses, title changes, better projects for hard work and accomplishments, look elsewhere.

- Lots of egos and different personalities to deal with.  Politics can be heavy depending on the department you are in

- Parking can be a pain if you work outside of normal hours.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: Really great health benefits, 401K plans, flexible spending accounts, commuter options (free shuttles and free transit passes), encouraged to take time to focus on wellness and given PTO and credits to do health screenings and take fitness classes.
cons: Working on the administrative end of the School of Medicine is a quagmire. There are countless offices and departments and a lot of people grandfathered into roles where they don't pull their weight. SOM has been operating lean for the last few years and don't hire enough full-time support to cover their growing faculty. This varies from department to department but overall there are a lot of overworked burnt out people. Change and innovation is a slow and grueling process here.

review_title: Lots of hype, disappointing reality, wasted potential.
job_title: Medical Simulationist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Brilliant faculty, beautiful campus, good benefits (for those that can actually use them), name recognition of the institution. The Stanford name carries more weight the farther you go from Palo Alto, and your relatives will brag about knowing someone who works there.
cons: Cut-throat academic bureaucracy, insultingly low pay, insistently incompetent managers, poor work-life balance, and thought police. The administration devotes far more time and resources to hyping mediocre programs than it provides for doing good work. Most programs are understaffed, and most employees are expected to do the work of two or more people.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, great work-life balance, generally easy to transition to other departments/roles (if wanted) so there is definitely opportunity for advancement for those ambitious enough to pursue it. Some really great employees and managers to work with, in my experience.
cons: Sometimes feels like high school with the amount of office politics and gossip that goes on. The pay is extremely low and not competitive at all to similar jobs in the market, making it almost impossible to live on if you are single and/or live alone. The benefits alone are what keep people here and anyone with a lot of experience or expertise need not apply if they expect to be compensated what they deserve. The cost of living in the area is outrageous so you're forced to live far enough away where it's affordable, making it a tough commute to work.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: Wonderful place to work. Full of enthusiastic, ambitious, intelligent, and capable young students, post-docs, PIs and administrative officials. The work environment in the research labs is very fast-paced. Lots of opportunities to expand skill-set including taking some coursework, lessons on management, entrepreneurship, outreach activities, etc. Several resources available to help advance career.
cons:
The fast-paced environment has a potential downside to it - high pressure situations. The publish or perish mentality is alive, well and thriving. Very difficult to overcome this traditional way of thinking even here, a region known for its early adoption of anything new and noteworthy!

Post-doc salaries although higher than NIH recommendations - are nowhere near sufficient to lead a non-student life.

review_title: Stanford University Research - get out what you put in
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Stanford, CA
pros: Amazing facilities, drive and passion of the people, with a supportive network of organizations, if you know where to look. World-renowned reputation, and a real feeling of cutting edge research through in every department.
cons: The experience of research fully depends on the deparment and your mentor, with inconsistent support networks for when those relationships break down. Can feel overwhelming and isolating as a post doc researcher, as graduate students have far more support. You have to really really put in the effort to network and outreach to truly get the best out of Stanford. Stanford postdocs are well paid for academic postdocs, but it is still really insufficient for the area surrounding.

review_title: Entrepreneurship is the buzz word, but there's the opportunity to learn, collaborate and grow here.
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Stanford, CA
pros: Access to great ideas, and an environment to come up with your own ideas. Learning about what others are doing. The weather and beautiful location. If you don't have what you need in your lab, just network/talk to other people and you'll find what you need. Access to career advice through peers, faculty, two career centers (School of Medicine and Career Development Center) and various seminars and talks by people in academia and various industries.
cons: Stipend amount is given according to NIH standards- 2-3yrs experience minus tax (in California)--> $3000/mo. Rents are high in a 10km radius from Stanford. Research pace towards publication can be slow.

review_title: Best place for academic research, at least in the Bay Area
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Stanford, CA
pros: There are not many places (or are there any?) you can have three Nobel Laureates in two years. This speaks for itself. And Stanford University is exceptionally rich and postdoc salary is higher than those in UC colleges.
cons: It is a very competitive environment, competition are there within the same department. There are a couple of cases of scooping the neighbors when I was there in four years. It is not a new thing in academia, heard that the labs in the East coast are even worse. Competition = Motivation, and people in academia never likes collaboration anyways, you take it or leave it.

job_title: Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: I am a graduate student at Stanford, but as they are my employer I am reviewing them anyhow.  I couldn't have asked for a better PhD program.  The students and faculty are all top notch. It is intellectually stimulating and you feel they really care about their students.  It was also possible to achieve work life balance if you want to.  Many people think it's difficult, but I rarely ever work weekends.  It is more of a personal choice.
cons: The cost of living in the area for a graduate student is absurd.  While Stanford pays more than other grad schools it all gets eaten up by housing costs, and then some.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Work life balance, 7:30 - 4pm I'm out. Tuition reimbursement $5250/year pretty good, supportive of continuing education. You just basically have to know what you want out of Stanford and milk 'em, then get outta there. Great benefits.
cons: Terrible pay, below industry standard. Everyone leaves Stanford because their supervisor sucks. Management is terrible across the board. Pay for parking on campus (uhh). Unfair pay -- depends on whether your boss likes you. Lots of favoritism.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: All my coworkers and most of management are very sincere and pleasant individuals that are all focused on getting the job done right. This work group has been the best I've ever worked with.
cons: Unfortunately, a new manager was hired for the department and this person made everyone's lives miserable! This one person affected so much negative change, that one by one this great and amazing group made the difficult decision to quit. It was very sad to see this happen and unfortunate for the department. HUGE LOSS!

review_title: It is what you make of it!!!
job_title: PhD Candidate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I am currently doing my Phd at Stanford. I feel that you get out of this place as much as you put in. Network with as many people as possible. As a student the Professors seem open to the idea of research collaborations and I took full opportunity of this. One major advantage is you begin to develop the 'Art of Thinking' of a problem as a result of working with people very accomplished at doing it.
cons: The housing situation is getting harder and harder to manage with the compensation provided and the lack of on campus facilities

review_title: Learned a lot; but very toxic work environment. It’s not worth it.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
--Innovative research studies 

--Hands-on patient contact running patient visits in the studies; Not just behind the scene paperwork coordinating

--A large variety of responsibilities for a single position so will gain a lot skills and experience in a short amount of time
cons:
--Pay is way below market rate for the position (lowest paying company in the Bay Area) and not a livable salary for how expensive the area is. They do not provide affordable housing options for staff to offset the low pay either. Their excuse for not paying us market rate for positions is “we are Stanford, we hold intrinsic value, we do not need to have competitive salaries”. 

--CRCA’s are not seen as a valuable part of clinical research teams at Stanford. We are just a tool for them to use to complete the PI’s research project and nothing more. We are not allowed to contribute ideas or feedback on the projects we work on or the lab; expected to be seen and not heard. Rare to receive mentorship from PI’s since they are busy doing other things outside of lab and it’s a low priority on their list of things to do.

--Common across all positions at Stanford is to hire one person for one position that has two positions worth of work. They Purposely understaff studies while still maintaining their high performance goals requiring the CRCA’s to work a lot overtime but then refuse to pay the CRCA’s for the overtime even though they are an hourly position (which is illegal). No work/life balance either. Under payed; overworked; under appreciated. This is Stanford clinical research labs.

--Experience with management varies by which PI you have. A few are great but there are a lot of bad PI’s at Stanford. They are good at science but terrible leadership/management and people skills. Micromanagement or completely absent PI’s, perpetuate hostile work environments. If you are unlucky enough to get one of the bad PI’s do not expect your lab or Stanford to step in. They do not let their PI’s go or reprimand them no matter what they do to their subordinates.

review_title: Great Benefits, Everything Else is Mediocre
job_title: Administrative Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Amazing benefits and incentives for full-time employees - Free VTA/Caltrain, healthier living incentives, 401k, PTO, sick time, vacation, and floating holiday
cons:
Terrible work/life balance
Micromanagement
Lack of seniority defaults to little respect
Not a team-oriented position, other positions in the company are very team-oriented 
Depending on your department, this specific position has very little room for growth
Lack of diversity
Salary is actual not as great as one would assume

review_title: Postdoctoral Experience at Stanford School of Medicine; Dept. Microbiology and Immunology
job_title: Post Doc in Stanford, CA
pros:
-Having Stanford on your resume give you at least a reply. 
-The culture is highly dependent on your group, so choose wisely. 
-People are open for collaborations.
cons:
-Choose your PI wisely. Not everyone are good, even though they are at Stanford. 
-Don't even think about other careers while at Stanford. The PIs want you to become themselves in several years, despite the lack of positions in academia. 
-Be ready to work at least more than 10 hours and every other weekend.

job_title: Administrative Associate in San Jose, CA
pros: Some flexibility with work hours, free Caltrain pass, lots of food options on campus.
cons: Seems to depend which department you land yourself in.  Management has little respect for administrative employees in my particular department.  There is no threshold for employees' workload, as those lower in the hierarchy tend to almost completely take on their supervisor's work over time, while supervisors go on vacation and frequently come into the office late and leave the office early.

job_title: Instructor in Stanford, CA
pros: BeWell incentive program, flexible schedule, opportunities to work with big names, connections to industry, strong reputation in academia as well as industry.
cons: Senior clinical fellows and instructors can be abandoned or considered low value to divisions. K grants, for example, are a source of soft money and free labor. Little to no incentive to assist with career advancement. Work culture depends on one's research group - choose wisely.

job_title: PhD Student in Stanford, CA
pros: great weather here! and you get to take lots of classes for free, almost anything under the sun from cooking to coding.
cons: the stipend won't even pay rent. graduate housing here is inefficient before they want a "village" feel so they're like space-inefficient one-story huts. commuting around campus is hard if you are not fit enough to bike fast.

review_title: Decent job, difficult to move up, people there for a lifetime
job_title: Recruitment Consultant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits. Golden handcuffs to the job. Really nice workplace.  Gorgeous campus.
cons: Salaries a little low for the area.  Supposedly made up for with the benefits, but more actual salary would be great.  People stay forever and know that because it is an "at-cause" workplace, it is VERY difficult to get fired once you are hired on. This leaves incompetent people in their positions for a LONG time making it difficult to make any radical changes. Traffic is a problem.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: Everyone is extremely intelligent and creative so it's a motivational environment to be in. The company itself is great as far as benefits, health classes, etc.
cons: While it's nice to be surrounded by ambitious people, it can be overwhelming at times. Things can feel very competitive and lonely work-wise. However, this seems to be on a person to person basis because the majority of people I've met are very willing to help and collaborate. In any case, the people are always friendly on a social level.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Great leadership and training opportunities - you will work hard to keep what you have... terrific benefits!
cons: They need to reclassify folks who have been there several years and mastered new and valuable skills that spread thru different levels of the department .  They hire new folks with fewer limited skills and pay them more :-(

job_title: Biochemistry Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: The environment is pretty collaborative and you'll be working with and around the best people in their fields.  Any expertise you need is likely on campus.  You'll work hard, but you really will learn to think like a scientist.
cons: Introduction to jobs outside academia was lacking, but is improving.  Like graduate school anywhere, you'll be underpaid and overworked, but that is pretty unavoidable.

review_title: Great place to work, high expectations
job_title: LSRP1 in Stanford, CA
pros: I love it here. The campus is beautiful, health insurance benefits are the best you'll find anywhere around (duh, they own the hospital). Extremely collaborative environment, great for networking and getting your foot in the door for industry careers
cons: Limited room for moving up in rank, and limited help with moving to another job within Stanford. I figured that working here would improve my chances of getting a job here in another department, but that doesn't seem to be the case

job_title: in Stanford, CA
pros: I worked part-time in the Medical School Office Building while I was an undergrad at Stanford. If I had not moved after graduation, I would have probably continued to work at MSOB because I thoroughly enjoyed it. I loved my coworkers and supervisor, I felt like I was making a difference in my work, and my hourly pay rate was fair.
cons: Cubicle life can be boring and monotonous at times. Luckily the people made it more enjoyable.

review_title: Good place to gain experience with the latest research
job_title: Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Gained new valuable skills and good experience to build upon.
cons: Poor working conditions and unprofessional supervisor

job_title: Administrative in Stanford, CA
pros: Benefits, but that is becoming worse as well.
cons: The bureaucracy at the school of medicine is HORRIBLE! To get from point A to point B can take months, I mean months! Stay away, there are far and few people who are willing to help one become successful. Training in a new position is non-nonexistent. Their motto must be, figure it out on your own. If your not faculty, your no one. So sad for such a great academic institute.

review_title: A good place to develop your career
job_title: Basic Life Science Research Associate in Stanford, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, very supportive staff, intellectually stimulating and plenty of things to do on campus. We are surrounded by a lot brilliant people and everyday is a new learning experience.
cons: This area is very very very expensive! Housing and rent almost eat up most of the salary. If you have kids, childcare is also beyond affordable. The health insurance premium increases every year and the coverage is not great at all.

review_title: Research Assistant @ Molecular Imaging Program at Stanford
job_title: Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Plentiful resources for research. Great place to connect with top-tier researchers. Frequent symposiums with renowned guest speakers. The campus is absolutely beautiful.
cons: The competition can be a bit intimidating. Interns are often given grunt work. The cafeteria gets very crowded during peak lunch hours.

review_title: Stanford School of Medicine hires the most talented candidates in the world and treats them like idiots.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros:
- Potentially good environment for growth. You can attend the top notch classes and meet the top notch faculties in the field. 
- The name Stanford may look good on the Resume ... or not. May gain some respect among peers.
- Location and weather.
cons:
- Most Stanford benefits are not available to the Postdocs.
- Postdocs are not eligible to officially register for a class and ear credits. In that case, some instructors are not willing to accommodate audits by postdocs. 
- The salary is a joke, compared to living expenses. 
- The management team does not live in the reality. 
- Lab space and working space is very competitive. You may not have a place to work and your lab may move from location to location very often. 
- Your lab may be even off campus and in that case, you are deprived of all cool seminars and events happening on the main campus. 
- The staff working in the departments are usually very rude to postdocs.
-  The subsidiary houses suggested by the Stanford itself does not approve your apartment application with a single Postdoc salary.

job_title: Life Science Research Assistant III in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stanford university employees seem happy, they stay around. Great benefits include generous 403b matching, generous vacation, and tuition assistance for employee and family members, use of gyms, transportation passes on trains and buses.
cons: For employees who must drive, parking passes are expensive. Employee contributions to health insurance can be high depending on the plan chosen. The salaries are lower than industry, but the benefits offset this.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros:
-Excellent reputation
-Good benefits (I don't use their medical insurance, but 410k is good. Also access to athletic facilities, Caltrain passes, etc)
-Great public transportation on/around campus (free shuttles, close to Caltrain)
cons:
-Hiring process/HR is awkward and slow
-Your experience will depend almost entirely on what lab/department you are working for. It's such a big institution that your day-to-day experience isn't really affected by the school much at all.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford university school of medicine offers a lot of freedom in an intellectual environment. Working hours are flexible and the vacation time is generous
cons: Costs for health benefits are increasing faster than salaries and the funding environment is challenging. You will spend more of your time looking for funding than doing research.

job_title: Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: everyone very nice and easy to work with. exciting research. lots of resources and all the equipment that you could dream of to do research
cons: a little bit distant from the PIs. didn't get to interact with them too much nor receive input on experiments from them.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: One of the top-tier research/medical schools with enormous resources.  Incredible network and opportunities in many fields.  Stanford will be a good place for a person who wants to go into academia or industry.
cons: Being a postdoc or graduate student,  salary/stipend is barely enough to survive in Bay Area.  Also there are no benefits.

review_title: Working at the School of Medicine
job_title: Finance in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
>Free food 30% of the time
>Relaxed hours but still 40+ a week
>Well kept areas
>Good pay
cons:
>lack of communication between all levels and within levels
>back stabbing
>politics
>abuse of power and money
>attitude of management
>lack of internal controls
>management lacked the knowledge to even complete their tasks...

review_title: Good to work with people and the resources to work for advancement of career.
job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Stanford is a stable environment, transportation is good, people are friendly, enjoyable work place.
cons: Very hard to get job but if you are well experienced fellow, you can get the job.

review_title: Great place to meet others with similar medical interest
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: Affiliation grants free usage of the gym, lots of lateral movement to other offices with same job description. Easy to commute using train.
cons: Takes time to get setup with all the trainings, and within my department management can get overwhelmed and slow down at peak hiring time periods

job_title: Faculty Affairs Administrator in Redwood City, CA
pros: Stanford benefits are terrific, and staff salaries are reasonable for the bay area. I was in the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, and it was a fantastic department. Faculty were generally very respectful of staff, and the administrative team were very supportive of each other.
cons: Bay area commute times are miserable.

review_title: Don't fall for the big name - Immersive Learning Center
job_title: Simulation Technology Specialist in East Palo Alto, CA
pros: You won't have to waste time or money on hobbies or a personal life, you'll always have challenging problem to solve and re-solve, you'll get plenty of exercise running around. Campus is lovely, if you can ever get out of the building.
cons: Entitled and sociopathic management, endless meetings, low salary, understaffing, no parking, no advancement,

review_title: Don't be fooled by the brand.
job_title: Post Doc in Stanford, CA
pros: Great seminars, libraries, pretty campus.
cons: Low pay, long hours, poor treatment of postdocs and staff often justified by the phrase "this is Stanford".

job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: You're surrounded with great, motivated people with a very positive attitude without the Silicon Valley cut-throat attitude. Very fertile environment for growth and development.
cons: If you're not used to academic institution complicated political landscape and decision making process it may discourage some.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits, there are a variety of different working environments to suit each person. Personally, my department is really flexible, down to earth and enjoyable.
cons: Medicine isn't generally my most desired work environment so it's not 100% suitable for me.

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Stanford, CA
pros: The Stanford name opens doors and adds immediate credibility to any work being done.
cons: Don't feel valued by employer or superiors. No effort on the University to help staff or faculty, but they also don't get in your way (which some peer institutions do).

job_title: Research Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: HR is great, benefits are great, a lot of Stanford pride.
cons: Barely any room for growth... not great for young budding professionals to stick around much.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stanford, CA
pros: The research laboratories at Stanford University are extremely well funded and attract the brightest people from across the world.
cons: Work can get competitive at times.

job_title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator in Stanford, CA
pros: great healthcare benefits really friendly staff and work environment, great facilities and benefits. bewell program and bike program reward you to be healthy.
cons: none so far. enjoy coming to work everyday, surrounded by great people who are all striving for a greater purpose..

review_title: Stanford's Med School has growing pains
job_title: Office Manager/Executive Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Exciting environment and driven by a passion to improve the health of all people.
cons: Always growing and adapting to current and projected requirements, the bureaucracy has recently become less supportive of the staff who enable and enact the changes.

job_title: Life Science Research Assistant (Casual Temp) in Stanford, CA
pros: Great work place, very functional, solid people.
cons: Temporary employees do not get caltrain ez pass, so I have to pay for my own train ticket which really adds up.  Coming from San Francisco it's $14 a day.

review_title: Challenging work on a beautiful campus surrounded by great thinkers
job_title: Research Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Beautiful work environment, wonderful employee benefits, good advancement opportunities, solid work/ life balance
cons: There is definitely some red tape regarding decision making which can sometimes hinder productivity.

job_title: Research Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Stanford works in cutting edge projects and you are surrounded by great minds and hardworking colleagues.
cons: Researchers are usually hired as part-time or independent contractors and thus do not have access to benefits. Stanford offers great benefits for full time employees.

review_title: A great place if you are interested in academic research
job_title: Bioinformatician in Stanford, CA
pros:
Academia has a wealth of opportunities for being part of various interesting research projects as well as publication opportunities.

It is also nice to have access to university facilities.
cons: Lower pay than industry equivalents

review_title: nice environment, great access to resources, mentorship was fantastic
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Stanford, CA
pros: good work-life balance. nice area, weather. lots of resources for postdocs. good collaborative environment
cons: competitive environment, need to be a self-starter. compensation is not great. career resources are not that great.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Stanford, CA
pros: Cutting edge research, great colleagues
cons: Ivory towers, politically charged culture, egotistical professors. No academic institution is perfect, but others (like MIT, Caltech, Berkeley) have a more science- and data-focused culture.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Post Docs in Stanford  have a very organized Postdoc association which helps on writing grants. There are many cutting edge tech ideas, and it's a very good platform
cons: It's focusing on more tech.

job_title: Graduate Student in Stanford, CA
pros: The weather and environment is great. Professors are world-class and value mentorship. There are tons of opportunities to network and advance your career.
cons: There could be more diversity.

review_title: Good place to work but not good to grow
job_title: Data Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very good working environment and good learning opportunity
cons: Working pace is a little bit low and compensation is not competitive

review_title: Would be perfect if not for the CoL
job_title: Laboratory Technician in Stanford, CA
pros: Outstanding benefits, good health plan, pretty good compensation
cons: Extraordinarily high cost of living, ceilings on salaries to maintain pay equality across the university

job_title: Executive Assistant in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Awesome benefits.... Great leadership (within our department) -- great colleagues...
cons: Sometimes opportunity for growth can be limited, but in a good environment, that's not always a bad thing.

job_title: Life Science Research Professional in Stanford, CA
pros: High standards, Excellent colleagues, Generous benefits.
cons: The commute is the only aspect I dislike, but the administration makes good efforts to mitigate this.
